entry.title: Movable type and the typographer's last words

p.small: Capital A in the font Ariella 36p. Ariella was used for printing flyers and stuff.

div.p: Waldermar Lundberg, my father, was born 1915. He was a printer and typographer and established a small workshop around 1947. The images here show some of the equipment he kept after his retirement 1975. He continued to work with printing and bookbinding until his death 2007.

p.small: The top case contains Garamond 10p, the rest is Berling 12p up to 24p in step of four.

div.p: All types were stored in rack cabinets like this. My father had a fairly complete set of Berling Antiqua, designed by Karl-Erik Forsberg (1914-1995) in the 1950s and produced by Berling type foundry here in Lund until 1980, when the company ended its more than 170 years in the graphical industry. The Berling Type Foundry was established in Copenhagen 1750 and continued its business there until 1783. It was then reestablished in Lund 1837.

Hand composing is significantly more complicated than typing touch on a computer or type writer. It is more like it than you would expect, though. You have to know where the types are, and they are not alphabetical order. Think of a QWERTY keyboard, but you have a large number of different space keys. Width equal to the width of l, n and m is just a start. There were spaces thin as paper. Think of the work to compose whole books having justified margins!
I worked several summers mid 1960s decomposing matrixes in the composing room, and I even did some smaller composing jobs. I think I could do it again.
Type pieces for large print was stored standing in rows. This could be the home for Ariella 36p.

Prior to his retirement my father had ten to 15 employees and an at times flourishing business. Among other things he was the second largest Swedish printer of time cards during the 1960s, and had also a not insignificant portion of the Norwegian market.

After his retirement he worked in this basement workshop for about thirty years. He had various printing presses including a fairly large modern offset press during a brief period. He kept these two old vintage tabletop printing presses until his death. He inherited one from a colleague and the other had been in his possession since the 1940s.

My brother, Torsten, and I donated one of the presses and a rack cabinet to a local museum. The rest of the equipment we sold to a young talented graphical designer Markus Sjöborg who has a small business in Malmö. He makes good use of this and other equipment he finds out there.
This matrix is for printing a text on a book spine in one of the printing presses. They are the last words typeset by my father.
